stream_context.summary: Kaze moves his dev streams from Twitch to YouTube based on community polls and monetization/ads concerns, then spends most of the session building and debugging a new Bowser-on-a-ship boss sequence (walk/run behavior, stepping up geometry, tail-grab/throw logic, sliding/dust, and animation needs). He also shares a major engine-side optimization to Mario 64’s floor-query logic (to both fix “floor clacking” and improve cache behavior), discusses ROM size pressure from streamed music under the 64MB limit, and briefly outlines a release/open-source strategy meant to reduce immediate Nintendo takedown risk.
stream_context.significance_reason: Introduces a concrete engine optimization with performance implications, establishes a tentative post-release open-sourcing delay due to Nintendo risk, and implements core Bowser fight interactions (grab/throw) while resolving refactor-induced bugs that affected object interpolation and animation timing.

findings.summary: Kaze says he is likely switching streams permanently from Twitch to YouTube after running community polls (most preferred YouTube), citing Twitch’s ad experience and the inability to comfortably follow two chats at once.

He highlights platform monetization differences as a reason to prefer YouTube (claims Twitch effectively takes ~50% while YouTube is closer to 70/30), framing Twitch donations as partially “donating to Amazon.”

He outlines the intended structure of the Bowser ship encounter: early phase should be easy, and each subsequent tail-grab/throw cycle should escalate (faster Bowser, more pressure). The player’s main verb is grabbing Bowser’s tail near an edge and throwing him off so he “jumps back” to his castle/ship state.

Boss AI/physics work focuses on making Bowser feel grounded rather than “floating”: adding a proper walk/run cycle, decelerating when leaving the run state, tuning turn speed (potentially scaling with damage), and fixing navigation failures by changing ship geometry to slopes/step-up-friendly surfaces.

Kaze describes a newly found floor-collision optimization: Mario 64’s find_floor_from_list stops after the first valid surface, which can cause surfaces to hide each other unless sorting is used. His approach keeps a useful sort priority but pre-filters “floors that are too high,” then loads only the upper/lower Y bounds (small subset of each surface struct) into cache so iteration touches ~0x10 bytes per floor, improving performance while avoiding the original floor-hiding problem.

He mentions continued engine-level math/physics improvements, including a “most correct” sine/cosine implementation and using complex/imaginary-number tricks to return multiple values efficiently in GCC (crediting a Discord suggestion).

A refactor/regression caused tutorial sign prompts to jitter/bounce in sync with framerate due to interpolation/spawn-state handling. He diagnoses it as a spawned-object interpolated position not being initialized correctly and fixes it by ensuring spawned objects set interpolated position properly (and by avoiding a helper function that interacted badly with per-frame offsets).

While implementing Bowser tail grabbing/throwing, he discovers broken interactions (e.g., unexpectedly punching Reznor) caused by a missing interaction subtype flag—an example of how a small behavior-setup omission cascades into seemingly unrelated bugs.

Kaze argues strongly against adding many user options (including refusing music-selection options), saying too many choices dilute a shared intended experience and increase confusion; he prefers shipping the “minimum options you can get away with.”

He claims the project is legal in principle but still proposes delaying open-sourcing for a short period after release so Nintendo does not “instantly” take it down; he also cites protecting Easter eggs as a secondary benefit.

ROM size is already heavily constrained by audio: he says the build is ~44.6MB, with ~32.1MB of that being music because RTYI uses a lot of streamed music (better performance/sound but huge file size), making the 64MB cap materially relevant for content decisions.

Kaze shares that he currently works as a kitchen cook and dislikes kitchen work (though he likes his current team), and that Patreon is his biggest income source. He also says he is already a professional Unreal Engine developer and would use Unreal for an original game, partly to earn more and to support long-term goals like buying a house.

He experiments with mitigating N64 background pop-in on ships/balloons: fog is possible but complicated by alpha sorting and multi-plane setup, so he tests a scale-in approach. He also notes an optimization technique for ships: negative scaling + face culling to reuse half-modeled geometry and reduce polygons, but it can introduce visual/culling edge cases if not handled carefully.

biobak.summary: Biobak sends Kaze a model for tutorial bunnies/sign prompts; Kaze reviews how the texture is split across multiple textures and uses it to prioritize adding/repairing tutorial textboxes and prompt visuals.

zeina.summary: Zeina speaks on-stream to clarify her role (animations/artwork) and plugs that she has been posting animations to her own YouTube channel; she says viewers can expect a new animation about monthly, with a Bowser showcase planned next.
On-stream couple dynamic: Zeina corrects Kaze’s joke about her being his “sister-in-law” and reiterates she is his wife, reflecting the casual, collaborative home-studio environment of development.

findings.summary: Kaze says a new Mario animation format being made by Lilaa is planned and will likely break existing content, but he accepts the short-term disruption because it improves the game long-term.
Kaze credits a Discord idea (from easyaspi) that uses GCC/complex-number tricks to return multiple values efficiently, part of his broader approach to micro-optimizing math/engine routines on N64.

key_stories.title: Floor-query optimization to fix surface hiding while improving cache performance
key_stories.summary: Kaze explains a long-standing Mario 64 floor-query pitfall (surfaces hiding each other) and how fixes can be expensive if done naïvely. He proposes a performance-conscious solution that preserves useful sorting while reducing memory touched per surface, framing it as one of the many RTYI engine optimizations he keeps discovering late in development.
key_stories.challenge: Mario 64’s find_floor_from_list stops iterating after finding a surface, which can produce wrong results when multiple surfaces overlap; sorting can help but creates other slope/ordering edge cases and costs performance.
key_stories.process: He keeps a form of sorting priority but pre-filters floors above a threshold and only loads the upper/lower Y bounds of each surface into cache, iterating a tiny fixed subset (~0x10 bytes) instead of the full surface struct.
key_stories.outcome: He reports improved runtime behavior/performance and a more robust fix against “floor clacking”/surface-hiding issues, reinforcing why he is postponing backporting optimizations to other branches until RTYI is finished.

key_stories.title: Turning Bowser from a 'Roomba' into a grabbable, escalating ship boss
key_stories.summary: The stream’s main practical arc is making the Bowser ship fight playable: grounded movement, step-up navigation, and tail-grab/throw interactions. Along the way, Kaze hits cascading behavior bugs triggered by missing flags and refactor side effects, illustrating how boss mechanics often require deep engine-state correctness (interactions, held-object transforms, interpolation).
key_stories.challenge: Bowser looks comical/floaty, can’t step up ship geometry, and the tail-grab/throw system has missing pieces (Kaze previously removed parts of Mario’s Bowser-grab logic). Bugs emerge where interactions and held-object transforms behave unexpectedly.
key_stories.process: He changes ship geometry toward slopes/step-friendly shapes, tunes Bowser state transitions (speed loss outside run, turning), adds/repurposes a tail hitbox and interaction subtype flags, and isolates issues by removing suspected held-object/rotation code until the culprit is found.
key_stories.outcome: Bowser can be grabbed/spun and the fight is closer to end-to-end playable, but animations and polish are still missing; Kaze identifies next steps such as sliding behavior, dust effects, and additional jump-back/transition animations (possibly Lakitu-assisted).

key_stories.title: Release planning under Nintendo risk: delaying open-source after launch
key_stories.summary: Kaze draws a pragmatic line between what he believes is legally permissible and what is strategically safe. He suggests holding back the project’s open-source release for a short window to reduce instant takedown risk and to protect secrets/Easter eggs.
key_stories.challenge: Open-sourcing immediately could make the project an easier target for rapid takedown actions, even if Kaze believes the work is lawful.
key_stories.process: He floats a concrete delay period (about two months) and ties it to both risk management and creative reasons (Easter eggs).
key_stories.outcome: A tentative release tactic is established that an interviewer can probe: what gets released when, and how the team balances transparency with survivability.
key_stories.key_quote: We should probably delay open sourcing the game a little from the initial release, just so Nintendo doesn’t instantly take it down.

open_questions.topic: Delayed open-sourcing strategy and takedown risk assessment
open_questions.context: Kaze proposes delaying open-sourcing after release (roughly two months) to reduce immediate Nintendo takedown risk and to protect Easter eggs, despite saying the work is legal.
questions: What specific scenario are you trying to avoid by not open-sourcing immediately—DMCA on downloads, a repo takedown, YouTube strikes, or something else?
How did you arrive at “about two months”? Was that based on prior experiences (yours or other modders), or a strategic guess?
What parts do you plan to open-source first (engine, tools, patches), and what—if anything—will remain closed longer?
Did you ever consult anyone (lawyer, other creators) about the legal/PR angle, or is this purely risk management from experience?

open_questions.topic: Audio memory budget: streamed music vs sequenced music tradeoffs
open_questions.context: He says the ROM is ~44.6MB and ~32.1MB is music because streamed tracks sound/perform better but are huge, making the 64MB ceiling a real constraint.
questions: What was the moment you realized music—not levels—was going to dominate the ROM size, and how did that change your content plans?
How do you decide which tracks must be streamed versus which can be sequenced without losing the game’s identity?
Do you have a target ROM size budget for non-music assets (levels, models, animations) as release approaches?
Have you explored hybrid approaches (short streamed intros + sequenced loops), or tooling changes, to claw back space?

open_questions.topic: Design philosophy of minimal options vs accessibility/comfort
open_questions.context: Kaze argues “options are bad,” rejects music-selection options, and prefers a consistent intended experience; he also makes blunt comments about not targeting blind accessibility for a 3D platformer.
questions: Where is your hard line between ‘too many options’ and ‘necessary accessibility/comfort’—camera settings, sensitivity, subtitles, colorblind support, etc.?
Did your stance on options come from a specific game you played (or shipped) where options harmed the experience?
How do you square a speedrun-focused design with minimizing settings, given speedrunners often want granular control?
If you had to pick one ‘exception’ option you would add, what would it be and why?

open_questions.topic: Movement feel changes that make RTYI 'built for speedrunning'
open_questions.context: Kaze highlights specific feel changes (e.g., long-jumping out of long-jump landing, jumping out of triple-jump landing) and says the game is “basically built for speedrunning.”
questions: What prompted you to allow cancels like long-jump-land → long-jump—was it a deliberate speedrun feature or an emergent improvement you decided to keep?
How do you test that movement changes still feel ‘Mario 64’ while enabling more skill expression?
Were there any movement tech ideas you rejected because they broke readability or level design constraints?
Do you expect the speedrun community to influence final tuning, and if so, how will you gather and act on that feedback?
